February 20, 2011: Fiction
TICK TOCK, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) The
New York detective Michael Bennett enlists the help of a former colleague to solve a
rash of horrifying crimes that are throwing the city into chaos.
THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf, $27.95.)
The third volume of the Millennium trilogy, about a Swedish hacker and a journalist.
THE HELP, by Kathryn Stockett. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $24.95.) A young white
woman and two black maids in 1960s Mississippi.
THE INNER CIRCLE, by Brad Meltzer. (Grand Central, $26.99.) An archivist
discovers a book that once belonged to George Washington and conceals a deadly
secret.
DEAD OR ALIVE, by Tom Clancy with Grant Blackwood. (Putnam, $28.95.) Familiar
Clancy characters appear as an intelligence group tracks a vicious terrorist called the
Emir.
FATAL ERROR, by J. A. Jance. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $25.99.) After the
murder of a cyber-sociopath, Ali Reynolds is drawn into a web of online intrigue.
STRATEGIC MOVES, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $25.95.) In the 19th Stone
Barrington novel, the New York lawyer works with the C.I.A. to transport a fugitive.
SHADOWFEVER, by Karen Marie Moning. (Delacorte, $26.) Hunting for her sister’s
murderer, MacKayla Lane is caught up in the struggle between humans and the Fae.
THE CONFESSION, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) A criminal wants to save
an innocent man on death row, but he must convince the authorities he’s telling the
truth.
ROOM, by Emma Donoghue. (Little, Brown, $24.99.) A mother’s prison is her young
son’s entire world.
THE SENTRY, by Robert Crais. (Putnam, $26.95.) The former cop Joe Pike finds that
a pair of Katrina refugees he helps aren’t all they seem.
BLACKVEIL, by Kristen Britain. (Daw, $25.95.) A contingent of Arcosian descendants
plan to bring Sacoridia to its knees. The fourth book of the Green Rider series.
WHAT THE NIGHT KNOWS, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $28.) Someone is murdering
entire families, recreating in detail a crime spree that took place two decades earlier.
THE RED GARDEN, by Alice Hoffman. (Crown, $25.) A mysterious garden offers the
key to understanding a small Massachusetts town through 300 years of passionate
history.
February 20, 2011
Non-Fiction
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner’s
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
THE PIONEER WOMAN, by Ree Drummond. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $25.99.)
The proprietor of ThePioneerWoman.com describes her marriage.
BATTLE HYMN OF THE TIGER MOTHER, by Amy Chua. (Penguin Press,
$25.95.) A Chinese-American mother makes a case for strict and demanding
parenting.
DECISION POINTS, by George W. Bush. (Crown, $35.) The former president’s
memoir discusses his Christianity, the end of his drinking and his decisions on
9/11, Iraq and Katrina.
CLEOPATRA, by Stacy Schiff. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) The last queen of ancient
Egypt was ambitious, audacious and formidably intelligent.
THE HIDDEN REALITY, by Brian Greene. (Knopf, $29.95.) A physicist explains
various theories involving the existence of parallel universes.
THE IMMORTAL LIFE OF HENRIETTA LACKS, by Rebecca Skloot. (Crown,
$26.) The story of a woman whose cancer cells were cultured without her
permission in 1951.
AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF MARK TWAIN, VOL. 1, by Mark Twain. (University of
California, $34.95.) Twain is pointedly political and willing to play the angry
prophet.
LIFE, by Keith Richards with James Fox. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) The Rolling
Stones guitarist’s revealing autobiography is also a portrait of the era when rock ’n’
roll came of age.
DECODED, by Jay-Z. (Spiegel & Grau, $35.) The hip-hop star leads a narrative
journey through his lyrics and his life.
IN THE BLINK OF AN EYE, by Michael Waltrip and Ellis Henican. (Hyperion,
$24.99.) The race car driver’s memoir is built around the crash that killed Dale
Earnhardt Sr. in 2001.
OUTLIERS, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Why some people
succeed — it has to do with luck and opportunity — from the author of “Blink.”
ASSHOLES FINISH FIRST, by Tucker Max. (Gallery, $25.99.) Stories of bad
decisions, debauchery and sexual recklessness.
SCORECASTING, by Tobias J. Moskowitz and L. Jon Wertheim. (Crown
Archetype, $26.) The hidden forces that shape how sports games are played, won
